answers.answer: Good luck to you.  I'm sure it will be fine.  Sometimes I wish I had had a C section since DD definitely did some damage down stairs if you know what I mean...Your DH can be trained.  I made my DH take a newborn class with me at the hospital which helped.

I'm high risk, too, because of having had a blood clot in my leg during last pregnancy. Honestly, I'm happy to be high risk...I like the extra monitoring and the once-a-month ultrasounds. I'm building a baby picture album starting with u/s at 6 weeks...how cool is that going to be? a photo album showing little baby develiopment from 6 weeks on?
thats cool... I really don't mind going in more often I just worry about preeclampsia and what could happen.... I just want this baby so bad.. so I praythanks for responding...

high risk is not a bad thing...cpatow is right they watch alot closer.  I wonder if it is normal to not be induced after c-section or if it is just your DR preference.  good luck all will be fine.  DH will get the hang of it:O)((Sheila))33w6d-Team Pink

did some research on the vbac thing and now I don't want one... 1 in 100 babies of vbac's die... that is not good... I was scared about the downs factor and this is much worse...  so I will just happily get the c section but I am a little sad that dh wont get to see me suffer through labor although it hurts... I loved it
WoW I didnt know that stat for VBAC....DH doesnt need ot see you suffer to know what a wonderful mom you are gonna be.  Time to enroll him in a DADDY BOOTCAMP  class :O)

I am also high risk.  I see my reg ob every week and the high risk dr every 2 weeks.  I get about 2 sometimes 3 ultrasounds a mnonth.  I am being monitored VERY closely and I love it!!  I also have a photo album starting at 5 1/2 weeks.

re VBAC, my old OB was willing to let me "try" going VBAC...until I developed my blood clot and we entered into an entirely different game. That was a C-section on steroids...they had a million more docs and nurses in there it seemed just in case something happened and I threw a clot and had a pulmonary embolism or worse. THAT was scary. I'm okay, obviously, but that experience taught me that even though normal delivery would have been "ideal", sometimes C-sections are the best thing since sliced bread!! Even though my C was scary because of my medical condition, the entire process was just magical. Birth is birth no matter how you slice it (no pun intended) Now, going into my 3rd c-section and even if I COULD delivery normally I would opt for "C". :0)Christina

my first c-section was after 36 hours of labor... she wanted to come out face first the little bugger... but I hope this will be better since I wont have to go through the labor also... I just remember afterwards when I wanted to get up it felt like my skin was ripping apart mmmm nice thought haha

Now you have me terrified about a c-section!  Yikes!  I've convinced myself I want a c-section w/ my twins regardless of whether or not they are breech and my dr said he will do whatever i want.  I've heard goog & bad but I really hope I don't feel as bad as you did afterwards since I will have 2 to take care of.  I REALLY hope you have a better experience this go-round & I'm sure hubby will be overjoyed regardless!dottie18wks 6days (twins)

My first c-section was after about 12 hrs of labor. Luckily it was not the kind of emergency that they had to knock me out.  My hubby was there holding my hand and talking to me, I was exhausted but it was fine and my recovery was not too bad.  I thought about trying v-bac with #2 but decided the uncertainty of labor again was more than I wanted to deal with.  It was yet to be scheduled but my water broke ten weeks early.  I was in the hospital for almost two weeks when my white cell count started to go up and the doctors figured it was better to deliver than risk an infection.  Anyway hubby was there again holding my hand and the whole thing was almost peaceful.  The recovery the second time was better, I think because I was not physically exhausted to begin with. Of course there are so many factors involved, you never know, but I do believe that a positive attitude going in helps a ton.  The important thing is healthy baby and healthy mom.

I'm right there with you. My first c-section was after 14 hours of labor. Baby didn't drop so had the c-section. Not an emergency one, so it went well. Tried to be supermom afterwards and that just prolonged my recovery. 2nd c-section: water broke 3 days early and baby won't drop again, so another non-emergency c-section. Took it much easier afterwards, napped when baby napped, recovery was much faster. A positive attitude and a good doctor are key. Good luck to everyone with their c-sections. Plus, my doctor said that c-sections help reduce the chances of incontinence in later life.

....the incontinence issue and stretching "down there" is one of the reasons why I'm SO happy I'll have been a "C" women with all 3 kids. Granted I have a tummy scar but it's below the bikini line and no one can see it but me :0).:0)

ok don't want to scare anyone haha... I think it was 36 hours of labor then a c secion... this time I will just go in and have one without all of the pain before... for those that have had c sections...did it hurt for you to go from laying to upright for you all.. . also last time my incision got infected haha... but oh well... at least i'll have my baby boo

ok don't want to scare anyone haha... I think it was 36 hours of labor then a c secion... this time I will just go in and have one without all of the pain before... for those that have had c sections...did it hurt for you to go from laying to upright for you all.. . also last time my incision got infected haha... but oh well... at least i'll have my baby boo

I've had repeat c-sections & I agree - it's much easier than having a c-section after a billion hours of labor (which I experienced w/my 1st).  I too didn't know the stats on VBAC's.  My dh's also never been around small children.  It should be interesting - LOL.

It's funny - I suppose just like a natural delivery - I know I hurt but I really don't remember.  The nurses always try and get you up pretty quick - the next day I think.  After my son I remember just standing at first then laying down again, then trying again and eventually making it to the bathroom.Directly after my daughter's birth, they had me hooked up to the drug machine where you push the button when you need to.  Unfortunately my machine was apparently defective because I was getting no relief from it (this was in recovery, right after surgery as the spinal wore off). Again I don't really remember the pain so much, just that I was crying and the nurses were freaking out, trying to get it going.  They finally got a Dr.s ok to give me a shot of Dilaudid.  That was the wierdest expierience of my life.  I felt like I was falling asleep for an hour but waking up to the next word of the conversation, apparently that evening I talked with my best friend for over an hour but I had no memory of it, needless to say there was no pain.  After that it was kind of the same, I hurt but it got better every day.Sorry if that sounds scary to anyone, like I said, I don't think of it as scary, just another piece of life that happened and gave me an interesting story.  You need to take care and allow yourself to heal, and also allow other people to help you.

question: she said that I can't be induced after a c-section...  so it looks like I will have another c-section which I hated... I really wanted my new dh to experience labor with me.. and plus after my c-section I felt like I couldn't be a mom right away change diapers and all of that... but I guess that is the way it goes...   Also dh has never been around little ones and has no idea of how to change a diaper or anything...Also she said that I would have an ultrasound in every trimester due to my high blood pressure and that I would have appointments every 2 to3 weeks instead of every month...hope all goes well with this little one... it makes me scared...
title: went to high risk obgyn appointment yesterday
